climbs.name: Ramp Route
climbs.fa: Dave Jensen, Mead Hargis and/or Dave Coughlin early 70s

content.description: This is the ramp on the north facing side of Lee's Peak and can be seen from Anthony Lake. Often holds snow late into the summer but can be by-passed by climbing on the face ramp of the ramp rather than in the corner. Three easy pitches of climbing can be found on the ramp. The second pitch which moves around a block can be challenging if water is present. Pro is solid but may be well spaced. The crack on the right side starts out quite large but narrows as it goes up.
content.location: Descend to the northeast to Angell Basin which is between Gunsight Mountain and Lee's Peak and returning to the Hoffer Lake trail.

content.description: To the left of the main ramp on Lee's Peak is a series of steep steps. Ramble through the path of least resistance. There are at least six routes in here that were established by Dave Jensen in the early 70s as part of Lute Jerstad's climbng/adventure school.
content.protection: Nuts and cams - a few pins may be found along the way
content.location: To the left of the main ramp on Lee's Peak

content.description:
Lee's Peak lies just aobve Hoffer Lake and has a granite ramp that goes up the NW face. There is one route on the ramp and to the left of the ramp are 6 or so routes (old pins can usually be found). 

  During the winter months the ramp is covered in snow. It has been skied and in the spring time when the snow is consolidatedit makes for a very moderate snow climb. During the winter and spring avalanche danger is present.
